title: Consumer Credit Rises At Slower Pace In August
text:
By David Harrison and Amara Omeokwe

WASHINGTON--Americans slightly slowed their pace of borrowing in August, the Federal Reserve said Monday, a possible sign that the cooling economy might be causing households to pull back on spending.

Here are some key details from the report:

--Outstanding consumer credit, a measure of debt excluding loans secured by real estate, rose at a 5.21% seasonally adjusted annual rate.

--The total amount rose by $17.9 billion in August from the previous month. Economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal had expected a $15 billion increase from July.

--Consumer credit increased a revised $23.05 billion in July from June, according to the Fed.

--Revolving credit outstanding, made up mostly of credit card debt, declined at a 2.16% seasonally adjusted annual rate in August after rising 10.48% in July.

--Nonrevolving credit outstanding, made up mostly of auto and student loans, increased at a 7.83% annual rate.
